Some museums are taking climate action and we need ALL cultural organizations to recognize their power to make a difference in a changing climate. "Despite the potential, authority, and capacity to engage their publics with the existential crises of our time the sector fails to live up to its promise." Learn how your organization can catch up in the essay by John Fraser and Sarah Sutton in the new book Museums and the Climate Crisis. https://lnkd.in/eHDdpmVM

I am grateful for the opportunity to participate in this wonderful initiative, which was made possible through my collaboration with the CIMAM International Committee for Museums and Collections of Modern Art. I strongly believe that art and culture are essential components of sustainability, as they play a crucial role in achieving the 17 SDGs set forth by the United Nations. With their educational and co-creative nature, museums significantly impact the well-being of individuals and society, and therefore, the Art Charter for Climate Action is of utmost importance. ART2023

Sports have good reason for caring about sustainability yet future Olympic games do need to adapt to climatic conditions if they are to take place at the peak of summer. The climate science is telling us of the probability that weather events, similar to what Paris has experienced (torrential rain follwed by intense heat), are likely to occur much more regularly depending on the climate scenario pathway chosen. We need to plan a climate resilient approach to such events and not simply rely on aircon, ice bags and schedule adjustment.

My eyes are focused on Olympics Paris 2024 prime time to watch the world‚Äôs greatest athletes gather to push the boundaries of human achievement. At the same time we are shattering global climate records.
